Award.AwardTitle: cROP: Common Reference Ontologies and Applications for Plant Biology
Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Pankaj Jaiswal (Oregon State University)

CoPIs: Dennis W. Stevenson (New York Botanical Garden), Sinisa Todorovic and Eugene Zhang (Oregon State University), Elizabeth Arnaud (Bioversity International/CGIAR, France), Christopher Mungall (Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory)

Senior Personnel: Barry Smith (University at Buffalo), Georgios V. Gkoutos and John Doonan (University of Aberystwyth, UK).

Plant researchers must be able to quickly search for genetic information from a wide range of online databases. Unfortunately, the researchers who originally provided the data and those who are analyzing it often use inconsistent terminology, making keyword searches less effective. To remedy this problem, the project will develop common gene annotation standards and a universal vocabulary of plant biology and diseases. It will also draw up standards and workflows for the creation and curation of such terminology. Additionally, it will develop a web portal and data warehouse to host this shared vocabulary and related annotation information to enable access by the broader plant community.

This project will create a centralized platform where reference ontologies for plants will be used to access cutting-edge data resources for analyzing plant traits, phenotypes, diseases, genomes, genetic diversity and gene expression data across a wide range of plant species. It will empower researchers to build hypotheses and discover, query, and analyze plant genomics data to address complex questions that would not otherwise be tractable. Ultimately, plant breeders can use this information to develop higher-yielding, more nutritious crops that tolerate stress and resist disease. As an educational component, the project team will reach out to K-12 and undergraduate students and the plant research community. Through this project, the scientific community will be able to contribute genetic annotation data to the warehouse via a collaborative web site that will also provide multiple ways to analyze and download data and other resources.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Rapid population growth and climate uncertainty are driving a critical requirement to produce higher yields and nutrient-rich crops that can tolerate or resist environmental stressors such as temperature, drought, and disease. The Common Reference Ontologies and Applications for Plant Biology (cROP aka Planteome) project, an international collaborative effort, is developing tools and data infrastructure to support the standardized description, analysis and exchange of data from a growing number of plant genomics and phenomics projects. The Planteome project has developed a suite of reference ontologies (common standardized descriptors) to harmonize data annotations that facilitate data integration, search and discovery. It developed and maintained reference Plant Ontology (PO), Plant Trait Ontology (TO), Plant Experimental Conditions Ontology (PECO) and crop-specific application Crop Ontologies (CO) with help from major plant genomics consortia, as well as large scale phenotyping and genome annotation projects representing a wide range of plant species. The project’s web portal (www.planteome.org) and novel data warehouse host and serve these reference ontologies and the associated annotated data. It also provides tools for data analysis, visualization, semantic reasoning, and community-based curation. The online portal and the data repository are the primary plant community source for ontology-enabled analysis of annotated plant genomics data. The project engaged students in ontology exploration, bioinformatics data analysis, software development and classroom STEM learning in plant biology and informatics. We also engaged plant biologists through face-to-face workshops, exhibits and online webinars, focusing on fostering ontology and data standards training, adoption and community curation of data and genome annotation.

The Planteome project is the primary reference resource for development, maintenance, sharing and distribution of ontologies for plant biology. This is the principal site for managing these ontologies for a global effort, thus fostering common data formats, description and exchange standards. We provide 19 million ontology-based standardized annotations of ~3M bioentities (data objects like genes, QTLs, germplasm, etc.) from 125 plant species.

The Planteome reference ontologies we serve are: the Plant Ontology (PO); Plant Trait Ontology (TO) and the Plant Experimental Conditions Ontology (PECO), all of which are continuing to be developed and maintained by the global team. Applications Crop Ontology (CO) describes eleven species and community-specific ontologies that are mapped and integrated in the Reference Ontologies. Both the reference and applications ontologies undergo active development and are maintained in a common organization and repositories on GitHub (https://github.com/Planteome). This allows ontology developers to have read and write access to these files, whereas anonymous users have read-only access. These files are distributed under the FAIR data principles and CC-by License. The project’s data browser is also mirrored at NSF-funded CyVerse (http://cyverse.planteome.org/amigo) for long-term access and use by CyVerse users.

  • Reference Ontologies developed and maintained by this project:
    • Plant Ontology (PO): Describes plant structure (anatomy, morphology) and plant growth and developmental stages (Developed by this project)
    • Plant Trait Ontology (TO): Describes plant phenotype traits
    • Plant Experimental Conditions Ontology (PECO):  Describes the treatment conditions for plant science experiments and the study types
  • Applications Ontologies
    • Crop Ontology: The following sets of crop ontologies describe species-specific descriptors for use in genome-phenome projects
      • CO_320 rice
      • CO_321 wheat
      • CO_322 maize
      • CO_324 sorghum
      • CO_330 potato
      • CO_331 sweet potato
      • CO_334 cassava
      • CO_336 soybean
      • CO_339 lentil traits
      • CO_341 pigeon pea
      • CO_343 yam
  • Other Reference Ontologies developed and maintained by partners
    • Gene Ontology (GO): Describes Molecular Function, Biological Process and Cellular Components 
    • Phenotypic Qualities Ontology (PATO): Describes observed phenotype qualities.
    • Chemical Entities of and Biological Interest (ChEBI): Dictionary of molecular entities focused on 'small' chemical compounds
    • NCBI Taxonomy: Describes NCBI taxonomy terms and relations in an ontology format
    • Relations ontology: Describes term-term relation types used in the ontology to generate a knowledge graph

The unique ontology resource for plant biology developed by this project is now an integral part of many projects and database resources on plant genomes, phenomes, biocuration, and genomics data archives collecting raw and providing annotated data.
